description: From Middle English linnen, from Old English linnan (“to cease from, desist, lose, yield up”), from Proto-Germanic *linnaną (“to turn, move aside, avoid”), from Proto-Indo-European *ley- (“to elude, avoid, shrink from”). Cognate with Danish linne (“to stop, rest”), dialectal Swedish linna (“to pause, rest”), Icelandic linna (“to stop, rest”).

verbs.description: lin (third-person singular simple present lins, present participle linning, simple past linned or lan, past participle linned or lun)

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, Northern England, Scotland) To desist, to stop to cease.
examples: Till all war deaun I knaw thou wad not lin.

description: From Middle English lin, from Old English līn (“flax, linen, cloth”). For more information, see the entry linen, lint.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, Ireland, Northern England, especially in compounds) Alternative form of line (“flax, linen”)
examples: a lin apron, lin-break, lin-brake, a lin cap, lin-clout, lin-garn/lin-yarn, lin-man, lin-weaver/lin-webster, lin-wheel
